G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: The Middlesex Superior Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 because the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, and the injuries occurred in Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the Defendant conducts business and the events giving rise to this complaint occurred in Middlesex County.

Dubuque v. Target Corp., 606 F.3d 33, 37.raw_text: Dubuque v. Target Corp., 606 F.3d 33, 37 (1st Cir. 2010)
Dubuque v. Target Corp., 606 F.3d 33, 37.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain its premises in a condition that was safe for invitees such as Plaintiff.
Dubuque v. Target Corp., 606 F.3d 33, 37.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a Second Circuit decision about trade secrets, agent agreements, and Connecticut law; it does not concern Massachusetts premises liability or duties owed to invitees. Nowhere does it discuss a defendant’s duty of reasonable care to maintain premises safe for invitees under Massachusetts law. Therefore it cannot be proper authority for the stated proposition.

Harper v. Rootes Motors, Inc., 340 Mass..raw_text: Harper v. Rootes Motors, Inc., 340 Mass. 675, 677 (1960)
Harper v. Rootes Motors, Inc., 340 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain its premises in a condition that was safe for invitees such as Plaintiff.
Harper v. Rootes Motors, Inc., 340 Mass..case_name: Cumberland Farms, Inc. v. Milk Control Commission
Harper v. Rootes Motors, Inc., 340 Mass..support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Harper v. Rootes Motors, Inc., 340 Mass. 675 (1960), but instead a milk price control case concerning the Massachusetts milk control commission and statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 94A. It does not involve premises liability, invitees, or any duty of reasonable care owed by a defendant landowner or occupier to a plaintiff. Therefore, this opinion cannot be used as authority for the proposition about a duty to maintain safe premises for invitees.
Harper v. Rootes Motors, Inc., 340 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The entire opinion concerns the authority of the milk control commission to fix minimum wholesale and retail prices for milk, and the interpretation of G.L. c. 94A, §§ 2, 10, 11, and 12. There is no discussion of premises liability, invitees, or a landowner’s duty of care to maintain safe premises.

Doherty v. Belmont, 396 Mass. 271, 275 (.proposition: Defendant breached its duty of care by failing to properly secure or stabilize heavy boxes stored at elevated heights and by failing to install safety barriers or straps to prevent their fall, creating an unreasonably dangerous condition.
Doherty v. Belmont, 396 Mass. 271, 275 (.support_reasoning: The case concerns a town’s duty as a landowner to maintain a parking lot in a reasonably safe condition and whether leaving a low metal parking-meter stub protruding from a median can constitute negligence. It does not involve the storage of heavy boxes at elevated heights or any duty to secure stored items with safety barriers or straps. Thus, while it supports a general duty-of-care/unsafe-condition principle, it does not specifically support the detailed proposition about securing elevated heavy boxes or installing barriers.
Doherty v. Belmont, 396 Mass. 271, 275 (.relevant_excerpt: “In the present case, the metal stub was not so insubstantial that it could not, as a matter of law, constitute negligence. There was evidence presented at trial that the metal stub was one half to three quarters of an inch high and surrounded by concrete; that this condition existed for a period of at least one year prior to Doherty’s accident; that the town through its agents knew that pedestrians walked on the median and that the parking meter stubs posed a risk to members of the public; and that the town nonetheless failed to take steps to eliminate this risk.”

Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (197.proposition: Defendant breached its duty of care by failing to properly secure or stabilize heavy boxes stored at elevated heights and by failing to install safety barriers or straps to prevent their fall, creating an unreasonably dangerous condition.
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (197.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (197.support_reasoning: The case concerns a slip-and-fall on a foreign substance on a stairway in a subway station, not the storage or securing of heavy boxes or the use of safety barriers or straps. The opinion addresses the duty of a premises controller to keep stairs reasonably safe and focuses on notice of a foreign substance and the time element for discovery and removal. It does not discuss elevated storage, falling objects, or any duty to secure heavy items with barriers, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (197.relevant_excerpt: "1. The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know."

Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.raw_text: Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 333 (1982)
Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and resulting damages.
Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses proximate causation and holds that a tavern’s negligent service of alcohol to an intoxicated patron can be found by the jury to be the proximate cause of injuries suffered by third parties, including the plaintiff and his deceased son. The court explains that, given the foreseeability of drunk driving, serving an intoxicated patron is sufficient to warrant a jury finding that the tavern’s negligence proximately caused the resulting highway injuries. Thus, the case supports the proposition that defendant’s negligence was the proximate cause of plaintiff’s injuries and resulting damages.
Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, evidence that a tavern keeper served intoxicating liquor to a patron the tavern keeper knew, or reasonably should have known, was intoxicated is sufficient to warrant a jury finding that the tavern keeper took such a risk, and that injuries to a highway traveler as a result of being struck by a vehicle improperly operated by the intoxicated patron, due to his intoxication, were proximately caused by the tavern keeper’s negligent act… A jury may also infer that service of liquor to an intoxicated patron is the proximate cause of injuries sustained by a traveler….”

Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.raw_text: Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341 Mass. 640, 644 (1961)
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.proposition: Defendant knew or reasonably should have known that stacking heavy items on high shelves without securing them created a foreseeable risk of harm to customers.
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.case_name: Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc.
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.support_reasoning: The case concerns a tavern keeper’s duty to protect a patron from assault by another patron and the standard of care owed in light of foreseeable violent conduct, not premises liability for the storage or stacking of physical items. There is no discussion of shelves, stacked items, or similar conditions, nor any holding about a duty to secure heavy objects on high shelves. Thus, citing this case for a proposition about stacking heavy items on high shelves misstates its holding and context.
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.relevant_excerpt: “Now, as far as the tavern keeper is concerned, it’s the duty of the person in control of a tavern or bar to exercise reasonable or ordinary care for the safety of a business visitor and to protect him from assault by other patrons and to use the highest degree of care in anticipation and prevention of violence by other patrons and even strangers as is consistent with the nature and the operation of the business… The test is ‘foreseeable harm.’”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 785 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant knew or reasonably should have known that stacking heavy items on high shelves without securing them created a foreseeable risk of harm to customers.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The case concerns a grape on the floor of a self-service supermarket, not the stacking of heavy items on high shelves. Its holding is that a self-service store has notice of inherent slipping risks from its mode of operation and may be liable if it fails to take reasonable precautions against foreseeable debris-related hazards. It does not address shelving practices, stacked heavy items, or unsecured merchandise on high shelves, so it cannot be cited as authority for that specific proposition.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, because the determination of reasonableness is a question of fact, the trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that a foreseeable risk stemming from the owner’s mode of operation could occur and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.… [A] store owner will be liable to a plaintiff injured as a result of a dangerous condition caused by a third party only if the owner could reasonably foresee that the dangerous condition could occur, resulting from the owner’s chosen mode of operation, and the owner took inadequate steps to forestall resulting injuries.”

Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.raw_text: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837, 842 (1987)
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.proposition: Defendant failed to take reasonable steps to address this hazardous condition, such as limiting the height of stacked items or implementing additional safeguards.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.support_reasoning: The excerpt addresses a duty-to-warn issue at a gas station, concluding there is no duty to warn customers about the obvious risk of negligent operation of other vehicles. It does not discuss taking reasonable steps such as limiting the height of stacked items or implementing additional safeguards against a hazardous condition. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition regarding failure to take such preventative measures.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant failed to take reasonable steps to address this hazardous condition, such as limiting the height of stacked items or implementing additional safeguards.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with premises liability for slip-and-fall on snow and ice and abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction. It does not address hazards from stacked items, limiting the height of stacked items, or implementing safeguards related to stacking. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for the specific proposition that a defendant failed to take reasonable steps such as limiting stacked item height or adding safeguards.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’”

Goodman v. Smith, 340 Mass. 336, 341 (19.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff sustained physical injuries, incurred substantial medical bills, lost wages, and endured pain and suffering.
Goodman v. Smith, 340 Mass. 336, 341 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the defendant’s negligence and upholds jury verdicts for personal injuries, but it does not detail the nature of the plaintiff’s damages such as medical bills, lost wages, or pain and suffering. It focuses on duty, notice, and breach in the landlord-tenant context, not on the specific categories of damages claimed in the proposition. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that plaintiff sustained those particular types of damages as a direct and proximate result of the negligence.
Goodman v. Smith, 340 Mass. 336, 341 (19.relevant_excerpt: "On the day of the accident the plaintiff went to the attic to store some dishes, assuming that the defendant had taken care of the floor. She placed them on the floor near the chimney and as she turned around to walk to the door of the attic a piece of board which was part of the floor slipped and her leg went through the floor and the ceiling of the third floor apartment. She sustained injury."

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff sustained physical injuries, incurred substantial medical bills, lost wages, and endured pain and suffering.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion discussing classifications of entrants on land (trespasser, licensee, invitee) and the appropriate standard of care for occupiers. It does not address elements of damages such as physical injuries, medical bills, lost wages, or pain and suffering, nor does it discuss proximate causation of such damages. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about the plaintiff’s injuries and resulting damages from defendant’s negligence.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.
